channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Egypt Set to End Sit-Ins Involving Tens of Thousands of People
item.description: An order by the government to security forces to break up the protests aroused fears of a new round of violent clashes.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Supporters of the deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, protested his ouster in Rabaa al Adaweya square in Cairo on Wednesday.

item.title: Head of Syrian Opposition Rejects Talks With Assad
item.description: Ahmad al-Jarba, president of the Syrian National Coalition, hardened his position and also said talks must be put off until the rebels made military gains.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Government forces patrolled on a street in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday.

item.title: Documents Show Thatcher-Reagan Rift Over U.S. Decision to Invade Grenada
item.description: Documents released by the British government said that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was angered by a lack of warning from President Ronald Reagan.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: In memoirs, Mrs. Thatcher described how dismayed and let down she felt by the invasion of Grenada.

item.title: Zimbabwe Vote Tests Long Rule of Mugabe
item.description: President Robert Mugabe, who has ruled since the end of white domination in 1980, does not seem ready to give up power, but he said he would respect the election outcome.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Some voters said they favored President Robert G. Mugabe because of his role in redistributing white-owned farms to blacks.

item.title: In Gaza, Iran Finds an Ally More Agreeable Than Hamas
item.description: Unlike Hamas, Islamic Jihad has kept up relations with President Bashar al-Assad, a longtime Iranian ally.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinian volunteers in Gaza Strip packed food for the poor. Organizers said that the Imam Khomeini Relief Foundation, a Beirut-based Iranian charity, was financing the $2 million food aid project.

item.title: U.N. Warns It Will Disarm Congo Rebels
item.description: In an uncharacteristically stern warning, the United Nations ordered individuals near the eastern city of Goma to turn in their weapons or be deemed “an imminent threat to civilians.”
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Some Syria Missiles Eluded Israeli Strike, Officials Say
item.description: American officials said that further Israeli strikes on Russian-made antiship cruise missiles were likely, after an attack in July failed to destroy all of them.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: U.S. Outlines N.S.A.’s Culling of Data for All Domestic Calls
item.description: The formerly classified papers outline a program that is collecting records of all domestic calls in the United States. Their release comes as top officials are testifying before the Senate.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, expressed deep skepticism about the domestic phone records program.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 31
item.description: Women in Andhra Pradesh welcome the central government’s endorsement of the creation of Telangana as a separate state.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Women releasing pigeons in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, as they celebrate the United Progressive Alliance coalition's endorsement of creating the new state of Telangana in Southern India.

item.title: The Lede: Reaction to the Manning Verdict
item.description: Pfc. Bradley Manning was an Army intelligence analyst who provided some 700,000 secret documents to WikiLeaks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Bills Unpaid, Power Is Cut To Province In Philippines
item.description: More than one million people lost electricity for more than 24 hours after a power cooperative was cut off for $92 million in unpaid bills.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Kerry in Pakistan to Discuss Drones and Afghanistan
item.description: John Kerry makes his first visit to Pakistan as secretary of state to discuss the fight against extremism, U.S. drone strikes, and Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Egypt Orders Police to Clear Protest Camps
item.description: Egypt's military-backed government on Wednesday ordered the police to clear two Cairo protest camps packed with supporters of ousted President Mohammed Morsi, saying they posed a threat to national security and were "terrorizing" citizens.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: Debate Over Controversial Delhi “Encounter” Continues
item.description: Debate over the controversial 2008 gun battle in Batla House area of Delhi continues.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA and MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting against the judgment in the Batla House encounter case in New Delhi on Saturday.

item.title: Letter from India: A Nation Shaped by Its Poorest Citizens
item.description: The elite in India are deeply influenced and affected by the nation's poverty.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH

item.title: India Ink: Dreams of a Mother
item.description: The struggles and ambitions of a domestic help in Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Akbari Begum Khan, third from left, with her family members at their home in South Delhi on June 18.

item.title: As Afghan Pullout Nears, Civilian Casualties Rise
item.description: The 23 percent rise in civilian casualties signals the challenge Afghan troops face as they take over the combat role from American forces.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Abdul Jamil, a victim of a suicide attack, lost an eye and suffers from a leg injury. He is helped by his wife in Kabul.

item.title: Report Says Spanish Train Driver Admits Reckless Speeding
item.description: Statement to prosecutors also quotes him as saying he will have to live with guilt for the rest of his life after crash killed 79 people.
item.dc:creator: By SILVIA TAULÉS and DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Paris Journal: A French Dining Staple Is Losing Its Place at the Table
item.description: The decline in bread consumption is so worrisome that a nationwide campaign is championing bread as promoting good health, good conversation and French civilization.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SCIOLINO
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Philippe Levin’s bakery in Paris, traditional, slow-baked breads are still much sought after and business has never been better, he says.

item.title: Pakistan Chooses Next President After Jailbreak Underscores Threats
item.description: Legislators elected Mamnoon Hussain, a supporter of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, hours after a Taliban attack freed about 250 prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: The Taliban attacked a jail in Dera Ismail Khan, where the police and soldiers gathered Tuesday.

item.title: United Nations May Fall Short in Food Aid for Syria
item.description: The World Food Program, which sought to help three million Syrians in July, cited intensified fighting in its inability to distribute more goods.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ERIN BANCO

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Paraguay: Land Dispute Is Renewed
item.description: About 200 poor farmers have reoccupied land where 6 police officers and 11 farm workers were killed last year in a violent eviction that led to the ouster of President Fernando Lugo.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Colombia: Rebels Set Terms for Release
item.description: A guerrilla army reiterated its willingness to free a former United States Marine, but it insisted that the Colombian government send a high-level delegation to retrieve him.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Saudi Arabia: 600 Lashes for Editor
item.description: The founder of a liberal Web site has been sentenced to seven years in prison and 600 lashes after angering Islamic authorities in Saudi Arabia, the newspaper Al Wattan reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Wife Is Accused in Death of Syrian Journalist Who Backed Assad
item.description: The wife of a pro-government Syrian journalist has been indicted, accused of having told her relatives to kill him last month, Lebanon’s state news agency reported Tuesday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
